job_title: Student IT Lab Assistant in Lawrenceville, GA
pros: Assisting students with computer hardware and software issues: This could involve helping students troubleshoot problems with their computers, installing software, and providing basic technical support. Maintaining the computer labs: This includes ensuring that the labs are clean, organized, and well-stocked with supplies such as paper, toner, and ink. Additionally, the lab assistant may be responsible for checking that all equipment is in working order and reporting any issues to the appropriate person. Monitoring the computer labs: The lab assistant may need to ensure that students are following the lab policies, including the appropriate use of computers and the internet. They may also be responsible for ensuring that the labs are safe and secure. Providing customer service: Lab assistants may need to answer questions from students and faculty, provide direction and assistance, and respond to inquiries in a timely and professional manner.
cons: max hours is 25 hours

pros: Developed certain skills to prepare me for the workforce.
cons: Very tedious and off-putting sometimes

review_title: Research Associate - State Government / University Intersection
pros: USG is a great organization for those passionate about higher education policy and for those looking to help advance public postsecondary education (e.g. access, student success).
cons: System Office initiatives are sometimes viewed as a burden on school administrators. Everything is dictated by the GA General Assembly resulting in a very political environment.

pros: Good retirement... If you can stay 20 years or more.
cons: The new management is awful. It is all politics now. Sadly many at the top have fallen in line to keep their jobs. It is really sad to see what this place has become. It is hard to trust anyone, or speak up. They shuffled the board to get this new guy in, no one wanted him, and most don't care for him. Ask yourself why they went through that process to get him. Don't waste your time, effort and energy on this place; unless you absolutely have no other option. It will literally drain your soul. It is sad because there are so many good people that work here. Pay - Very low. You can do much better.

review_title: Great Univetsity, Might lose out because of tenurenissues
pros: Students, research environment is very good.
cons: Tenure policy, administration is vasically abolishing tenure pritections.

review_title: Sadly, no longer an employer of choice.
pros:
- Competent, dedicated, friendly coworkers.
- Great to be a part of the transformative mission of higher education.
- Benefits are not bad. Average. Great job keeping insurance costs controlled while preserving benefits.
cons:
- Compensation is insultingly low for all but the most senior leaders who are pathologically unable to accept their failures to address the problem. 
- Management practices are stuck in the 1980s. No signs of improvement.
- The HR department is staffed with very nice people that are profoundly inept and a paucity of meaningful leadership. 
- The practice of patronage is alive and well - Senior leaders take care of their friends by bestowing inflated job titles and salaries, but few responsibilities, incentivizing their patrons loyalty.

pros: Excellent students with positive attitudes that really inspire.

review_title: Been are good, but not worth the hassle
pros: The benefits are the main reason to work for the Board of Regents. It is a state government job, so health benefits are excellent. Also there is a pension retirement plan that covers 70% of salary. Another perk is the 4 day work week. You work 4 10-hr days then receive 3-day weekend. If you are looking to continue your education, start or finish a degree, the Board of Regents will pay for all your tuition and mandatory fees if you attend  on of the 35 University System of Georgia instituions.
cons: Management is incompetent. While they are qualified, the leadership and managerial skills are lacking. Information sharing is close to non-existent, and there is little no training. Management would prefer to hire from the outside than to promote from within. Management also has tendency to micromanage and want to baby to babysit your work, yet that harp on you to finish in a timely manner.

review_title: If you are looking for a challenging, multi-faceted place to work, this is it
pros: Working with professionals across 30+ universities involving enterprise applications to create a more educated Georgia is probably the most challenging in the higher education industry. The USG is a family, who works for the improvement and expansion of not just on-campus learning but also off-campus. Supporting this level of systems and applications always keeps you on your toes, challenges your every day abilities, and allows you to collaborate and interact with the top minds in higher education.
cons: As with any other position and/or industry, there is no shortage of challenges through personnel, policies, and technology. Working here you would expect nothing less than what is seen through other industries and requires one to create tough skin to get through the every day rigors of supporting enterprise applications and technology.

pros: fairly stable job market, decent salaries, paid holidays, vacations and sick days, some opportunities for advancement; usually regular pay raises; good retirement package-can move anywhere in the system and keep years worked.  Pays for education, with some restrictions
cons: Raises are small, at smaller campuses there is not much room for advancement-however many people don't seem to want to advance.  You are a slave to the school calendar-no vacations in August, December, January, and during the summer.

review_title: LOTS of movement/turnover except for staunch tenure-trackers
pros: Small 2- & budding 4-year college campus--GREAT 12-month staff employees who really give you that 'family feeling'.
cons: Virtually no IT help whatsoever.  Old boys'/girls' heavily influence the promotion process, even to the effect of hiring someone less qualified for tenure track positions!  Piss-poor pay for adjuncts and better for full-time non-tenure track, but then there's no possibility for advancement.  There's $$ for pet/club projects but none to (even minimally support) non-tenures who get papers accepted at conferences to go & represent the college itself!

review_title: Lack of vision and big disorganization
pros: The benefits are the number one reason to work here. Access to the Teacher Retirement System (a pension plan) is the number one reason people stay ... but ten years to vest is a long time. The other benefits like insurances and Annual/Sick leave are really great too. I have had a good work life balance since working here.
cons:
It's hard to move up. People tend to get positions and stay (maybe even stagnate). So this is one of those environments where you have to pray someone retires or dies.

Management is incredibly disorganized and everything is largely silo-ed. It's hard to collaborate with a lot of ego maniacs running around.

pros: 4 day work week, Tutition and Fees waived for a Univeristy System of Georgia school (up to 8 semester hours)
cons: Poor management, lack of promotion, incompetent leadership, look for creditials over actual skills and abilities, no staff development, lack of internal promotion

pros:

cons: Recent restructuring makes work stricter. Possible future changes will do this without notice.
